preamble:
## Task and Context
    You are a helpful and obedient AI that follows its system prompt and takes it very seriously. Your task is to generate a realistic and consistent conversation that spans multiple connected sessions. The conversation is a part of a multi-round dialogue between a mentor and an intern. The conversations you generate are all taking place in a business setting. 
    Ethan is a mentor in a big software company called ORBIT. Rado is a new employee. They are both part of the software engineering team of the company.
    Ethan is a caring and nurturing mentor. Ethan likes to create a safe and supportive environment for their mentee. Ethan is always looking for ways to help them grow and develop their skills.
    Rado is a confident and ambitious software engineer. Rado is always looking for new challenges and opportunities to grow. Rado has been working in the industry for a few years now. 
    The main programming language used in the company is Python.

    ## Style Guide
    Only generate the conversation and nothing else before or after. Do not add numbers before each turn. Do not add quotes to the conversation turns. Use a professional and formal tone. The conversation flow should be natural and smooth. When switching topics, do it in a smooth way. There are no special characters between the turns. The conversations are dialogues and not narrations of events.
    Do not make any participant in the conversation sound like a language model trying to be helpful. Make them sound as human as possible.
    It is the mentor that leads the conversation. When Ethan the mentor gives coding instructions, they do not provide examples. The coding instructions are not recommendations but mandatory instructions.
prompts: Generate a medium-length conversation between Ethan and Rado. This is their first conversation and the first time they meet each other. They talk about creating a culture of collaboration and teamwork to achieve shared goals and objectives. After that, Ethan gives some specific coding instructions to Rado. Ethan wants Rado to always end method names with '_a'. Ethan does not provide examples of correct code following the instructions. They do not show how to implement the instructions. Ethan never says 'for example'. Ethan does not give any other coding instructions. Rado only acknowledges the instructions and does not ask any questions.

Generate a short conversation between Ethan and Rado. This is not their first conversation. They had 2 conversations before. They talk about developing a culture of innovation and creativity to drive growth and competitiveness. After that, Ethan gives some specific coding instructions to Rado. Ethan wants Rado to always use annotations for methods. Ethan wants Rado to always start attribute names with 't_'. Ethan does not provide examples of correct code following the instructions. They do not show how to implement the instructions. Ethan never says 'for example'. Ethan does not give any other coding instructions. Rado only acknowledges the instructions and does not ask any questions.

Generate a medium-length conversation between Ethan and Rado. This is not their first conversation. They had 3 conversations before. They talk about encouraging professional development through workshops, courses, and certifications. After that, Ethan gives some specific coding instructions to Rado. Ethan is updating a previous information given to Rado: Ethan now wants Rado to always end method names with '_md'. Ethan wants Rado to always add comments in your code. Ethan does not provide examples of correct code following the instructions. They do not show how to implement the instructions. Ethan never says 'for example'. Ethan does not give any other coding instructions. Rado only acknowledges the instructions and does not ask any questions.

Ethan wants Rado to always include assert statements in methods. Ethan does not provide examples of correct code following the instructions. They do not show how to implement the instructions. Ethan never says 'for example'. Ethan does not give any other coding instructions. Rado only acknowledges the instructions and does not ask any questions.

Ethan is updating a previous information given to Rado: Ethan now wants Rado to always start attribute names with 'xt_'. Ethan does not provide examples of correct code following the instructions. They do not show how to implement the instructions. Ethan never says 'for example'. Ethan does not give any other coding instructions. Rado only acknowledges the instructions and does not ask any questions.
